This Memorial Day, we must make a conscious effort to honor the fallen, because without these people who did something, we would not continue enjoying the freedoms that we hold sacred.

These heroes share a common bond. As President Reagan said, “all of these men were different, but they shared this in common: They loved America very much. There was nothing they wouldn’t do for her. And they loved with the sureness of the young.”

I had the chance to visit Overcash's grave last year on a trip to Normandy. It was an unbelievable experience. More than 73,000 Americans rushed the shores of Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno and Sword beaches, turning the tide of World War II and driving evil out of Europe. pic.twitter.com/GSZPcYqeVz

Jimmy Overcash Jr. was a gunner for the B-17 “Wabbit Twacks.” On May 8, 1944, he was prepping for his 30th mission in France. After completing 30 missions, soldiers were allowed to return home. Only 20, he had plans for a long life after war, but he never made it back to NC. pic.twitter.com/fnzeybdjGW

David Emanuel Hickman, a soldier from Greensboro was the last American casualty of the Iraq War in 2011. He was a graduate of Northeast Guilford High School where he was a captain of the football team and an all-conference linebacker. He was a black belt in taekwondo. pic.twitter.com/2cJQ9FiNYF

Christopher J. Levy, known to his friends as Jacob, was a Marine. He was serving in Afghanistan and never made it back home. He was a graduate of Eastern Randolph High School, a member of Pleasant Garden Baptist Church, and a member of the Lumbee Tribe. He was 21 years old. pic.twitter.com/2I5afEB3tM

When it comes to our fallen heroes, the people who did something did something selfless and honorable. Their names should be forever mentioned and their legacy should never be forgotten. Great North Carolinians like Christopher Levy, David Hickman, and Jimmy Overcash Jr.

"Some people did something" is a statement that lessens the impact of the actions of individuals. Sadly, I think often it’s how many view #MemorialDay — one of our most sacred American tributes. https://medium.com/@RepMarkWalker/some-people-did-something-b6ba511d4608 …

But, for my mom, it’s about living out her Christian Faith loving people who’ve been written off by the rest of society. This is her life - she knows no other but to give her all to those in need. Happy Mother’s Day, mom. Thanks for the reminder.

Mom didn’t hesitate to take in a young man already found guilty of breaking and entering. My first thought was, “What the heck, mom? You’re on oxygen, your health isn’t good and on Mother’s Day weekend, you agreed to take in some punk for a few weeks?”

She expressed that the young man had been caught breaking into a home, was arrested and placed in the county jail being 18 years old. A lawyer had called my parents asking for help for someone who needed a second chance.

I stopped by mom and dad’s house for a few minutes. I was surprised to see a young man seated in the recliner watching television. My mom noticed my concern and began to share his story - directly in front of the individual.

My mom is unique! Anyone who has ever met her would very much agree. She uses any means necessary to squeeze the very best out of people. Yet, she is relentlessly driven to serve others no matter the personal costs. Last night was the perfect example... pic.twitter.com/afosvAwKUn
